short_description: This session supports participants to get clear about what’s important to them
session_objectives: Participants will identify core values

id: Participants will explore how they prioritize their values,Provide participants with 4 totes/buckets and ask them to label each bucket as aspects of their lives (e.g. family
short_description: relationships etc) by attaching sticky labels on the buckets. Invite participants to write on small cut up sections of pool noodles all the demands and expectations they feel from each of the labeled buckets. Reflective questions during this process may include: How does it feel to name these demands? What’s it like to hear that others feel the same demands? How hard is it to categorize these? What similarities are there between the buckets?

id: Provide participants with 4 hula hoops and ask them to identify 4 values that they live by (e.g. integrity
short_description: respect
specific_focus: accountability etc). Assign a value to each hula hoop and invite them at one end of the arena/pasture with the horses at liberty. Bring in the buckets and place them in them at the opposite end.

id: Wild Card Game: Participants must transfer demands from the buckets and place them into the value hoops corresponding to the demand. They can only move one demand at a time. If a horse interacts with a bucket
short_description: or demand (pool noodle piece) in any way (e.g. sniffing
session_objectives: stepping on/in etc)
detailed_session_plan: that item becomes a priority. The group must then decide immediately how to “prioritize” the item.

id: Participants can interpret the rules of the game. Facilitator to invite reflections on how they adjust to changing priorities/demands/expectations. Reflective questions: What’s it like when things change? What support do you need when the unexpected happens? How might we ask the horses for support? What happens if we view the horses as helping rather than being a “wild card”?

short_description: This session focuses on communication between horses and humans and highlights choice, agency, and assumptions in the interactions
session_objectives: Participants will explore the differences between choice and agency.

id: Participants will gain insight into the assumptions they make in how they communicate,This session works well for any “getting to know you” stages of groups. The aim of the activity is to find out what the horses like/dislike. In the process of doing so
session_plan_name: participants will explore the ways in which they offer choices and agency
short_description: and the assumptions that they might make about others.

id: Begin with a safety briefing
session_plan_name: followed by inviting participants to meet and greet the horses. Have a selection of grooming tools available of different sizes
short_description: shapes
specific_focus: and textures and clipboards with paper and pens. Participants may work in pairs/small groups depending on the size of the group. Ask each group to decide on their roles of “Explorer” or “Data Collector”. An additional role of “Evaluator” can be included if working as trio. The “Explorer” is responsible for finding out where the horse’s favorite spot to be groomed is
session_objectives: and with what grooming tool. The “Data Collector” keeps track of where the Explorer has groomed and with what tool. Encourage participants to come up with their own “measurement” or scale to document the horse’s reactions. The “Evaluator” can be the one that assigns the score based on the feedback from the “Explorer”. If in pairs

Facilitator can pay attention to what that brings up for the participants and how they relate to this process. Re-group after 10-15 minutes to gather feedback. Repeat with different horse and debrief.
Reflective questions to include: “How is your horse telling you what they like?”
session_plan_name: “How do you know if they like it?”
short_description: “What do you imagine they like/don’t like about that?”
specific_focus: “What assumptions might we be making about what they’re saying/doing?”
session_objectives: “What choices are available to you (or the horses) right now?”

id: Closing session can include questions about what they discovered about the horses/each other/themselves in their expedition.

short_description: This is a longer session that can be expanded over the course of 2-3 hours. Aimed at working with families to help increase awareness of non-verbal communication.
session_objectives: Participants will work together to achieve a common goal

id: Participants will gain insight of the impact of non-verbal communication.,Participants stand in a circle with palms facing each other. Facilitator can demonstrate activity with one family member to play a game of “Lead or Follow”. Ask participants to designate one person as leader. Ask the leader to begin moving their hands in different directions with palms facing family members on either side. Participants follow and shadow hand movements of people on either side. Switch to a new leader after a few minutes and then debrief. What is it like to lead? What is it like to follow?
Begin the same exercise but this time without designating who is leader or follower. No speaking
session_plan_name: just movement to see what happens organically. Who is following? Who is leading? Is it clear? Encourage participants to move their feet so that they are not static in one spot. How are they navigating their surroundings? What does “leading” mean in this family? Debrief experience.

id: Give the group a long lead line. Invite them to begin walking together with everyone holding the lead rope. Pay attention to space and pace of movement and distance/proximity with each other. Who is leading? How do you know where to go? Pause and offer additional instructions: This time when facilitator rings a bell
session_plan_name: participants need to change EITHER their speed or direction. Complete 4 or 5 rounds of changes and pause for debrief: What was it like to change speed/direction? What made you choose to go at that speed? How does this show up in your everyday lives?

id: Highlight what assumptions participants made about leading/following. Transition to focus on herd observation and invite participants to watch horses at liberty in arena/pasture. Who is leading/following? How do they know? What assumptions or stories are coming up for them about the horses and their relationships? How do these stories show up in their relationships?
After safety briefing
session_plan_name: enter the space with the horses. Ask participants to bring their lead rope with them. Repeat exercise in the space with the horses by walking around while holding to lead rope. What additional considerations do they need to pay attention to? What happens when the family is in a different environment and/or changes are needed? How did they decide where they were going?

id: Invite participants to decide collectively a pathway that they would like to walk around the arena/pasture while being mindful of where the horses are. Remind them that everyone needs to hold onto the rope as they navigate the designated pathway while paying attention to how the horses respond to them. Pause intermittently to ask reflective questions such as: “I notice that __ is on the move. Where do you think he’s going?”
session_plan_name: “What’s it like to see him up close?”
short_description: “How can you stay connected while allowing him to pass between you?”

id: Invite participants to take all that they’ve learned from the session into the final activity. “How might you include the horses in your walk now
session_plan_name: without using the lead rope between you or with the horses?”

id: Closing session: highlight what shared communication looked like during the experience. How might that translate to how they communicate outside of the barn? What needs to be supported or made clearer to enhance connection? What was it like to see family members in a different setting or role? How will this create change within the family unit?
,Facilitator can begin the session by asking the family what their shared hope is for the session. The inconsistencies of what isn’t shared will often show up in the activities. During the session
session_plan_name: pay attention to the pace of how the family completes the tasks - especially during Step 3 - as often “changes” will result in speeding up rather than slowing down. Highlight what impact that may have on family connection. When walking with the horses
short_description: be mindful of safety and positioning. ,Ensure that horses are comfortable with working with groups. Pay attention to spacing
session_objectives: and/or high energy from the group. Make sure that horses have space to retreat to if they choose not to engage in the activity. ,Instead of ringing a bell indicate change
detailed_session_plan: invite the family to pick 4 “family anthems” - music with different beats/tempo and play clips of the tracks. Slow doesn’t the process and pay attention to how they choose the music. What family dynamics are in play in the choosing? Who leads/follows? How does that show up outside of the therapy space? Invite participants to notice what feels different with each track and pay attention to what memories might come up through the music. Participants can then choose their favorite track that they feel allowed for the most connection when they go into the pasture with the horses. How do the horses respond to the music? ,Instead of providing lead ropes

equine_welfare_considerations: facilitator can incorporate some mindful breathing with each other and the horses before inviting participants to walk with the horses. short_description: This is a longer session that can be expanded over the course of 2-3 hours. Aimed at working with teams to help participants create shared vision and cohesion.
session_objectives: Participants will work together to achieve a common goal

id: Participants will gain insight into their leadership/followership styles,In pairs
session_plan_name: participants stand with palms facing each other. Facilitator can demonstrate activity with a volunteer to play a game of “Lead or Follow”. Ask participants to designate themselves as partner A or B. Starting with A
short_description: ask them to begin moving their hands in different directions with palms facing. Partner B to follow and shadow hand movements. Switch roles after a few minutes and then debrief. What is it like to lead? What is it like to follow?

id: Find a new partner. Begin the same exercise but this time without designating who is leader or follower. No speaking
session_plan_name: just movement to see what happens organically. Who is following? Who is leading? Is it clear? Encourage participants to move their feet so that they are not static in one spot. How are they navigating their surroundings? Debrief experience.

id: Form 2 or 3 groups and give each group a long lead line. Invite the group to begin walking together with everyone holding the lead rope. session_plan_name: participants need to change EITHER their speed or direction. Complete 4 or 5 rounds of changes and pause for debrief: What was it like to change speed/direction? What made you choose to go at that speed? How does this show up in your team at work?

id: Highlight what assumptions participants made about leading/following. Transition to focus on herd observation and invite participants to watch horses at liberty in arena/pasture. How do these stories show up in their relationships within the team?
After safety briefing
session_plan_name: enter the space with the horses. Ask participants to re-form the groups as before and bring their lead ropes with them. What happens when the goals shift at work and/or changes are needed?

id: Invite participants to decide as a whole group a pathway that they would like to walk around the arena/pasture while being mindful of where the horses are. Ask them to tie all lead ropes together to form one long rope. Everyone needs to hold onto the rope as they navigate the designated pathway while paying attention to how the horses respond to them. Pause intermittently to ask reflective questions such as: “I notice that __ is on the move. Where do you think he’s going?”
session_plan_name: “What’s it like to see him up close?”
short_description: “How can you stay connected while allowing him to pass between you?”

id: Invite participants to take all that they’ve learned from the session into the final activity. “How might you include the horses in your walk now

id: Closing session: highlight what shared vision and cohesion looked like during the experience. How might that translate into the workplace? id: 2. Participants will explore sound-making as a way of expressing connection or curiosity.

session_objectives: or repetition. No instructions are given beyond invitation to listen and play.

short_description: This session explores anxiety through movement, observation, and sensory props. Participants choose how they want to engage with the space and the horses, building awareness of their voice, visibility, and choices.

Invite participants to experiment with voice amplifier/microphone connected to bluetooth speaker as they walk around the pasture with horses at liberty. how are the horses responding to them as their volume changes? Can they hear each other? What's it like to not be able to hear or be heard? Can they see each other? What's it like to be able to see but not hear and vice versa?

short_description: This session explores the themes of power and control through creative expressions in interactions with horses.

session_plan_name: prepare 3 different “playlists” of music that incorporate 3 different genres (e.g. classical
short_description: drumming
session_objectives: country
detailed_session_plan: rock). Begin by inviting participants to listen to 1 minute of a track from each genre. Ask the group to decide which genre they want to explore more of with the horses.

id: Invite participants to select 2 tracks from the chosen playlist that feels activating or soothing. This can be done in view of the horses. Facilitator can notice how the horses respond to the music while participants are choosing their tracks and incorporate observations into the process (e.g. How are you choosing the tracks? Which track do you think the horses like?)
Once tracks have been chosen
session_plan_name: invite participants to enter into the space with the horses while playing the first “activating” track. Ask participants to notice how the horses are responding to their presence and the music. What stories might be coming up for them? What are they noticing in their bodies? How does their energy shift with the track? What does the music represent? Themes of power and control - who is in charge of the music? What choice do the horses have? How can we allow for more collaboration? How can we support more choice?

id: Repeat with the “soothing” track. What’s different in the horses? What’s different in our bodies? How do these different rhythms impact how we want to connect with others (or not)? What about volume? Who’s in charge of volume and what does that mean in the context of participants’ lives? This process can repeated multiple times with different types of music/rhythms depending on time available. Facilitator can pay attention to group dynamics during this process and highlight themes of power/control - who has control over the music

short_description: This self-care session combines aromatherapy and breathing techniques to ground and center participants.
session_objectives: Participants will practice breathing techniques as a way to anchor sense of self.
detailed_session_plan: Provide a selection of aromatherapy oils and fabric pieces of different shapes, sizes, and textures. Ask participants to choose an oil, fabric, or combination that feels like an expression of who they are and ask them to share their choice with the group.

session_plan_name: lead the group through some breathing exercises. Start by breathing in their chosen scent on the fabric and invite participants to notice where there is tension/relaxation in their body. The group then enters the space with horses at liberty. Working in pairs
short_description: participants introduce their items to the horses. They are encouraged to notice how the horses respond and reflect on what that response means for them. Horses may be at liberty to approach participants to explore the scented fabrics. Invite participants to continue breathing exercises with the horses. Option to offer sensory exploration of breathing in the scent of the horses - how do they smell different/same? Notice how the horses respond to being sniffed. What does that mean for the participants? Are they horses sniffing the participants or their items? What’s the difference for them?

,Allow plenty of time for reflection. Ensure that there are abundant choices available. short_description: This session invites participants to explore how they see themselves and how they belong using creative props to express themselves.
session_objectives: 1. Identify one thing that helps/hinders their sense of belonging.
detailed_session_plan: Begin by inviting participants to share a color that resonates with how they feel in the moment. Have paints, chalk, and rocks available and ask participants to select a rock that represents aspects of their identity. Allow time for participants to paint/draw on the rocks to create a symbol of how they see themselves. This part of the session can take place in view of the horses. Ask participants to notice how the horses are responding to the group activity. Participants may choose to paint/draw on a rock to express the identity of one of the horses that they are particularly drawn to. Debrief the creative experience as a group.

id: Participants are then invited to bring their rocks into the space with the horses at liberty. They can choose to create a common area to construct a rock pile of their creations and/or hold their rocks and go to the horses to introduce themselves to the herd. Participants can choose to engage with just one horse or going to each horse
session_plan_name: or approach horses in pairs or as a group. Ask the group to pay attention to how the horses are responding to them and their rocks. Adapt questions to specific client age/population to process what the horses might be feeling/thinking about their rocks. For those who made rocks of the horses
short_description: how accurate were their expressions of the horses? Which rocks are the horses drawn to and why? If opting for a collective rock pile
specific_focus: how are the horses responding to the rock pile? Are they more interested in one in particular? Why might that be? How does that translate to how the participants feel about the horses and themselves? e.g.

id: - What did you notice about how the horses engaged with your rock?
- What does this tell you about how you experience visibility or belonging?

Debrief can include what the participants want to take with them and/or leave behind. What do they want to do with the rocks? What will they remember about the interaction with the horses?
